_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Background
Commonwealth Agri-Energy is an ethanol production facility located at 4895 Pembroke Road on the southeast side of Hopkinsville, Kentucky.  The facility began production in the spring of 2004.  

When the facility reaches full production capacity, it will process approximately 7 million bushels of wheat and corn grown within the Hopkinsville area. Annually the plant will produce 20 million gallons of fuel grade ethanol plus another 58,400 tons of distiller?s dry grains (DDGS).

Commonwealth Agri-Energy is subject to RMP regulations due to the storage of ammonia in excess of 10,000 pounds.

Chemical Management Program
As a concerned member of the communities in which Commonwealth Agri-Energy is located, the company takes its role as a responsible corporate citizen very seriously.  The facility is operated to protect employees, contractors and the public from injury and illness, and to minimize environmental impact.  The plant?s safety program stresses safe conditions and safe practices.  Commonwealth Agri-Energy?s policy is to inspect, maintain and operate equipment and facilities to prevent accidents, including release of hazardous materials; and to train employees in prevention, as well as to prepare them to respond rapidly and effectively should an accident occur.

Commonwealth Agri-Energy has developed and implemented a Process Safety Management (PSM) plan as part of an overall chemical management program.  The program involves a wide range of senior management personnel, including the Environmental and Safety Coordinators.  Additionally, regular safety meetings are conducted to discuss a wide variety of environmental, health and safety training issues.

Commonwealth Agri-Energy currently has one (1) process that contains a regulated substance covered by EPA?s 40 CFR Part 68 (anhydrous ammonia).

Description of Regulated Substances - Anhydrous Ammonia
Ammonia is used to control pH in initial stages of the ethanol production process.

Ammonia is added to a tank where it is mixed with corn slurry.  The ammonia is liquefied by pressure and stored in an 18,000 gallon aboveground storage tank located between the ethanol production facilities and the ethanol storage tank area.  Ammonia is conveyed to the slurry tank through a 1-inch steel pipe at a distance of approximately 256 feet.

The tank and piping system are equipped with several safety devices to mitigate an accidental release.  The primary safety devices are excess flow valves that are designed to automatically close and prevent excessive release of ammonia from the storage tank.

Off-Site Consequence Release Scenarios
This information is being withheld due to security concerns.

General Accident Release Prevention Program
Commonwealth Agri-Energy maintains a Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals plan prepared in accordance with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) regulation 29 CFR 1910.119.  The elements of the PSM program include:

Commonwealth Agri-Energy? PSM program includes the following elements:
-Process Safety Information,
-Process Hazard Analysis,
-Operating Procedures,
-Training,
-Mechanical Integrity,
-Incident Investigations,
-Compliance Audits,
-Management of Change,
-Pre-Startup Review,
-Contractors,
-Employee Participation, and
-Hot Work Permits.

As part of the release prevention program, the system is equipped with relief valves and safety systems designed and installed in accordance with industry standards.  These systems are designed to prevent a catastrophic release of ammonia.  Commonwealth Agri-Energy also utilizes a preventative maintenance program for its system components to ensure they are in good operating condition.

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidents involving ammonia at this facility since production began. 

Emergency Response Program
Commonwealth Agri-Energy has implemented an Emergency Response Plan in accordance with the OSHA PSM regulations.

The written Emergency Response Plan contains specific information regarding Emergency Response organization and procedures, as well as incident notification, mitigation, and incident preparedness.  

Commonwealth Agri-Energy works closely with the local emergency responders (i.e., Hopkinsville Fire Department and Christian County LEPC) to ensure coordination during an emergency situation.  In addition, Commonwealth Agri-Energy conducts emergency response refresher training for plant personnel on an annual basis.
